node.text:
Get ready for Spring with these flower themed activities! 💐

🌸Blooming paper flowers: Watch as the flowers magically bloom!
🌼Fizzy flower rainbow: A colorful classic!
🌷Chromatography flowers: Watch colors separate from marker ink and create a colorful flower bouquet.

Do you think you will try these?
Let me know below! ⤵️
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Everything is more fun with a rainbow!
🌈 Traveling Rainbow: Learn about color mixing and watch new colors appear.

🌈 Skittles Rainbow: Watch the rainbow spread, but not mix!

🌈 Magic Rainbow: Create a rainbow that magically appears!

🌈 Hidden Fizzy Rainbow: Watch as the colors appear and fizz!
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Create some Valentine’s Day magic that your kids are sure to love! 💕

🌈Valentine’s Skittle Rainbow: Kids will be mesmerized as the colors spread, but do not mix!
💗Fizzing Hearts: This fizzy science will literally melt your heart!
🎨Heart Art: Use science, salt, and watercolors to create art you will love!
💖Conversation Heart Oobleck: You will be all heart eyes 😍 as you watch the colors swirl and mix as you play!

💕Do you think you will try any of these ideas?
Let me know below! ⤵️

Save this post for later & share with a friend!

For more Valentine’s Day inspiration followed along with #valentineplay .
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#toddleractivities #preschool #creativekids #efys #earlylearning #homeschool #activitiesforkids #activitiesfortoddlers #toddlerscientist #valentinesday #toddlersofinstagram #toddlerlife

node.title: Four Science Activities with a Valentine’s Day Theme

node.text:
Preparing food for meals or snacks is a great way to get your toddler involved in practical life work. Making (and eating 😋) smoothies has quickly become one of E’s favorite activities 😀. Our Toddler Tower from @sprout_kids allows him to independently access the counter and he uses it everyday to help in the kitchen! 🙌🏻
.
For the smoothies, we don’t follow a recipe, but they usually include a mix of fruit, avocado, and peanut butter. I portion out the ingredients and place them in small bowls or pitchers for him to independently dump into the blender. I put the peanut butter on a small spoon, so he can more easily transfer it into the blender. This is the most challenging step and he usually asks me to help. But on this day he decided to do it on his own. (Watch to see why 😉😁).
.
He also enjoys pouring the smoothie into the tumblers, so I put some smoothie into a small pitcher for him to pour.
.
Do you have a favorite smoothie recipe or smoothie ingredient?  Let me know below! 👇 I’m always looking for new ideas!
.
Age: 26 months
.
Small bowls, pitcher and smoothie tumblers are listed in my Amazon shop.
Both boys enjoying eating their smoothie at their weaning table from Sprout-Kids. (Link in my profile).
.
.
.

node.text:
This weekend, E helped make a cake to celebrate M’s birthday! 🥳 We decided to make a low-sugar pumpkin cake, because we had already had most of the ingredients!
.
However, this post isn’t about the product (I honestly don’t think I would make this recipe again 😬), instead it’s more about the process!! 😁
.
If you have been following along with E's baking, you know that the past few times I shared a baking post, E licked his fingers if he got an ingredient on them (NOT good to do with raw flour 🤦🏻‍♀️). This time I provided him a cloth and told him to wipe his hands if he spilled anything on them.
The video is longer than I normally share because I was so proud when he followed directions and used the cloth to wipe spilled flour off his hands. And he did this TWICE! 🙌🏻😍
.
E has been practicing his pouring for awhile and his skills have greatly improved! He also helped mix the ingredients and put sprinkles on top! 😄
.
I love watching his skills develop in the kitchen and his independence blossom. 🤗
.
Do you bake with your little ones?
.
Toddler Tower is from @sprout_kids . Use discount code: INSPIRED10 to save!
.
Chef hat and apron are listed in my Amazon shop. 👨‍🍳
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Happy Shelfie Sunday! Quick tour of our play space and playroom shelves!
.
The top two rows of the shelf are dedicated to my 25-month-old, but my 11-month-old can now reach the second shelf, so I am always mindful of what I place there. On the bottom, I place toys I think my baby will be interested in, and often my toddler also plays with these! (My 11-month-old’s main toy shelf is in our living room).
.
Currently on the shelf we have:
.
- Magnifying glass (@natural.playbox ) and bugs (@safariltd ) (both available on Amazon).
- Threading rabbit (@redbarntoys ).
- Ten frame with wool balls (gift).
- Stacking pebbles (@grimmswoodentoys and @lovevery ).
- Shape match (pieces from various puzzles).
- Animals (@schleichofficial ).
- Sliding top box and ball (@lovevery ).
- Lock boxes (@guidecraft_official from Amazon).
- Ring stacker (@heirloomkids ).
.
- Seagrass baskets are from @natural.playbox .
- Wooden trays and white baskets are from Amazon.
.
On the top of the shelf, I am keeping some arts and crafts for my toddler. (playdough, @stabilo colored pencils and dot markers) and a small sensory bin with some tools.
.
In the playroom, we also have a shelf with our sunflower sprouts in a jar (see my last post), two Water Wow art books and a block set.
.
⭐We also have a table and chair set (@sprout_kids ), which my toddler uses to do his tray work and activities. Use discount INSPIRED10 to save!⭐
.
.
.
#montessoriathome #montessoriinspired #preparedenviroment #playroominspo #toyrotation #playroomideas

node.text:
My little baker helped make Irish Soda Bread this afternoon! I pre-measured the ingredients and placed them in various bowls and pitchers for him to pour into our mixing bowl. Helping in the kitchen is relatively new for him, but he did a great job transferring the ingredients into the bowl! He even helped with the mixing!

Having children help with food preparation is a great activity to get them involved in the daily rhythm of the household. Do you have any plans to cook or bake with your littles during the next few weeks? Let me know below! 👇

Toddler Tower: @sprout_kids (Discount code: INSPIRED10)

node.text:
SENSORY BOTTLES 

Put oil and water in a clear bottle to make an easy sensory bottle. 

Here I used an oil-based food coloring to color the oil and a water-based food coloring to color the water.

These are great to use with a baby during tummy time! But older children will also love watching the oil and water separate as the bottle is flipped.

💡You can also add pom-poms or water beads to your sensory bottle!

Don’t forget to glue the lid on your bottle!

Note: If you color the oil, the coloring will eventually merge into the water. 

Have you ever made a sensory bottle? What did you include in it?
.
.
.
.

node.text:
DIY I-Spy Bottles

These are so simple to make and always a hit for kids that enjoy I-Spy. 

To make:
Place small figurines and a filler (we used dyed rice) in a clear bottle.
Glue on the lid, so your little one can’t open it.

These are the perfect DIY for kids to make and great for vocabulary development as kids point out and learn the names for each of the items!

Do you think your child would enjoy this? 

Figurines: Good Luck Minis from @safariltd (discount: INSPIRED)

Plastic bottles: listed in my Amazon Storefront 

Wooden heart tray: @jackandlinktoys 
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
FIZZY CHALK PAINT

I can't believe it's already August!
Have you made chalk paint this summer?
The basic recipe is only two ingredients, of course I added a third for a fizzy surprise!

To make chalk paint combine:
- 1 tablespoon cornstarch
- 1 tablespoon water
- 2-3 drops food coloring
*For fizzy chalk paint, add 1 teaspoon of baking soda.

Make different colors in small bowls or a muffin tin.
Using a paint brush, draw on your sidewalk or driveway!
For the fizz, use a dropper or spray bottle to add vinegar on top of your dried art!

Tip: If your chalk paint begins to harden in your muffin tin, simply give it a stir with your paint brush!
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
HIDDEN COLORS

Fizzy play is always a favorite go-to activity!
This version is easy to set up, the color reveal along with the fizz has a “wow” factor, plus using a dropper is a great way to develop finger muscles (which are important for writing!)

DIRECTIONS:
1️⃣Place baking soda in a muffin tin.
2️⃣Stir in food coloring.
3️⃣Cover with more baking soda.
4️⃣Add vinegar to reveal the hidden colors!

Learning benefits:
- Fine motor skills
- Identifying & naming colors
- Learning about color mixing
- Learning about cause & effect

Have you tried this one before?
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Anyone else love #bookishplay ?🙋🏼‍♀️

We love using our toys to bring books to life and the new Magna-Tiles® Safari Animals set is perfect to use with one of my kids’ favorite books: “Dear Zoo”.

The Safari Set includes four magnetic animals (all also featured in the book): elephant, giraffe, lion and chimpanzee.

We also put our creativity to the test and used our Magna-Qubix to create the other animals in the book! 
Swipe ↔️ to see our camel and snake!
 
Which animal would your child be most excited about?

Stop by my Stories today; I will be sharing sneak peeks of the other Magna-Tiles Animal Sets.

➡️Details on the animal collection:
Launches September with pre-orders on Magna-Tiles website on August 9

There are three sets in the collection (each retails for $39.99):
🦁Magna-Tiles® Safari Animals 25-Piece Set
🐊Magna-Tiles® Jungle Animals 25-Piece Set
🐧Magna-Tiles® Arctic Animals 25-Piece Set

The Magna-Tiles set was g i f t e d to us.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
GELATIN EGGS

Gelatin makes a great taste-safe sensory base! 
Here, I used flavorless gelatin (less sticky) to create sea turtle eggs.

TO MAKE:
1️⃣Sterilize your egg shells by boiling shells in water for at least 10 min or bake at 220F for 10 minutes.
2️⃣Make your gelatin according to the package directions.
3️⃣Place a small figurine inside the eggshell.
4️⃣Pour in gelatin.
5️⃣Allow gelatin to set before play.

To play, you can either allow your child to peel away the shells (great fine motor activity) 
OR you can peel away the shells and give your child the gelatin eggs to play with!

You also could create “eggs” without the figurines inside. 

See my last post for information on the taste-safe sand used in this setup!

❗️Remember to supervise young children with any small objects and use parental discretion when determining what play activities are suitable for your little one! 💕

Happy playing!! ❤️
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Taste-Safe “Sand”

When looking for taste-safe sensory options, head to your pantry!
To make this “sandy” beach, I put dried oats in the blender for a few seconds and it makes a great beach to scoop and pour!

🏖Other suggestions for taste-safe “sand” include: crushed cereal, graham crackers, crackers, or brown sugar!

SAVE this idea and check back later this afternoon; I will be sharing a video of how to make these sea turtle eggs! (Hint: Remove the shell and they are also taste-safe 😉)
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Have you heard of aquafaba?

It’s the liquid from the can of chickpeas and makes awesome (and edible 🙌🏻) play foam!🤯

TO MAKE MIX TOGETHER:
- Liquid from a can of chickpeas
- ⅛ teaspoon cream of tartar*
- Food coloring (optional)

It only takes about 5 minutes to whip up!

Next time you make hummus, save the liquid and try this play foam!!

Note: I recommend making it shortly before you want to play, as it will start to deflate and turn back into a liquid over time.

*Cream of tartar acts as a stabilizer and helps the aquafaba whip up and form stiff peaks; you can omit it but the foam may not be as fluffy.

I added some @safariltd figurines (discount INSPIRED) to our play foam ocean!

SAVE this idea for later
SHARE with a friend!

Do you think you will try it? Let me know below! 👇🏻
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
TASTE SAFE SENSORY PLAY

What does “taste-safe” mean?
S A V E this post to refer back to!

If your child is still mouthing things, “taste-safe” means it’s not harmful for them to put the material in their mouth. However, a material may be “taste-safe”, but still not something you want your child to eat handfuls of (for example, uncooked rice).

Some taste-safe items are also edible, basically anything that you are using for play, but could also give your child as a snack. For example, yogurt paints, pudding, and cereal are all examples of “edible” sensory play. 

Even when something I’m using for sensory play is “taste-safe” or “edible”, I usually discourage my children from eating it. This helps them learn that items for play are not to go in their mouth and generalize this rule to things that are not taste-safe.

When possible, I also set up sensory play in an area that is separate from where they eat. This also helps them learn to distinguish between things for play and those that are for snacking.

🐚Here, I setup a simple seashell matching activity: find a shell and match it to the printout.
🏖The “sandy” sensory base is taste safe bulgar wheat! 

Do you enjoy this information and advice regarding sensory play?
Let me know below!👇🏻

For the next couple days, I will be sharing more taste-safe sensory play options!

Remember to always supervise young children during sensory play and be aware of possible choking hazards.

Seashell printables are from @morntingstogether .
Discount code: INSPIRED10 

Wooden letters from @jackandlinktoys

Round tray and brush from @chickadeeswoodentoys
Discount code: LITTLELEARNERS10

node.text:
If you’ve been following in my Stories, you know my kids have been really interested in doing puzzles lately. I use this easy storage solution to save space while storing puzzles!

🧩Place the puzzle pieces and a photo of the completed puzzle in a zippered pouch. 
🧩Place the pouch in a storage container or on a shelf and it takes up way less space than keeping the puzzle in the box!

This #storagehack also works for wooden puzzles (great to easily keep the pieces with the board) and board games!

➡️ Zippered pouches are listed in my Amazon Storefront under “Playroom Storage”
➡️ Puzzles also listed in my Amazon Storefront.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
OCEAN FIZZY PLAY
Ending the week with some ocean fizzy play courtesy of @themagickfolk .

We will be continuing with our ocean play next week and I plan on sharing some taste-safe sensory ideas! 🌊

Have a great weekend! 💕

🐟Fizzy play is the Deep Sea Adventure Potion from @themagickfolk
🐟Bio plastic cutters, sea glass shapes and bamboo scoops from @chickadeeswoodentoys 
(Discount: LITTLELEARNERS10)
